numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph compares the frequency of communication between young men and their parents and the frequency of communication between young women and their parents.
2. The graph considers three communication methods.
3. The first communication method is sending texts.
4. The second communication method is phone-chat or video-chat.
5. The third communication method is visiting in person.
6. Young women communicate more frequently with their parents than young men communicate with their parents.
7. This difference holds for all communication methods.
8. Sending texts is the most common communication method for young men and young women.
9. The largest gender gap in communication frequency is for sending texts.
10. The smallest gender gap in communication frequency is for visiting in person.
11. Young women visit their parents more often than young men visit their parents.
12. There is a noticeable difference in communication frequencies between genders.
13. I wonder why this difference exists.
14. Gender norms may influence these communication patterns.
15. Upbringings may influence these communication patterns.
16. I wonder how these communication patterns will shift when people are older than 30 years.
17. I wonder what the data would show for people in their early twenties.
18. I wonder what the data would show for college students.
19. I am a college student.
20. My community contains mainly busy individuals.
21. For many young adults, moving out from the parents' home marks a transition to more independence.
22. The frequency of contact with parents varies widely among individuals.
23. The proximity to parents can affect the frequency of contact with parents.
24. Work schedules can affect the frequency of contact with parents.
25. The nature of the parent-child relationship can affect the frequency of contact with parents.
26. The headline is: Staying Connected: Young Women Lead in Family Communication.
